tasks.title: Task #424: Implement Basic Visual Representation System for Building Damage
tasks.description: Develop a visual feedback system that represents different building damage states through sprite management and overlays, providing clear visual cues for damage progression and events.
tasks.details:
This task involves creating a comprehensive visual representation system for building damage that builds upon the core damage system (Task #422) and integrates with the building module system (Task #423). Implementation should include:

1. Design and implement an overlay system for representing early damage states:
   - Create visual assets for different damage types (dirty, dingy, chipped, cracked)
   - Develop a layering system that can apply multiple damage overlays to a single building sprite
   - Ensure overlays are positioned correctly regardless of building size/orientation
   - Define overlay asset requirements and file structure (e.g., /assets/overlays/)
   - Specify layering logic and Z-ordering for overlays

2. Implement base sprite management:
   - Create a sprite registry (SpriteRegistry class) that maps building types and modules to their sprites
   - Develop a system to load and cache sprites efficiently (using a singleton pattern)
   - Implement proper Z-ordering to ensure damage overlays appear correctly
   - Define Z-ordering rules for base sprites and overlays

3. Develop state-based sprite switching:
   - Create a mapping between damage states (from Task #422) and visual representations
   - Implement logic to switch sprites or apply overlays based on damage thresholds
   - Ensure smooth transitions between visual states (e.g., fade, crossfade, or instant switch)
   - Plan for extensibility for future damage types

4. Implement visual feedback for damage events:
   - Create temporary visual effects that trigger when damage occurs (flashes, particles, cracks appearing)
   - Develop an event queue/manager for queueing and displaying multiple damage events
   - Ensure visual feedback is distinct and noticeable to players while remaining non-intrusive

5. Integration requirements:
   - Connect to the two-axis damage tracking system from Task #422
   - Support the module-specific damage visualization from Task #423
   - Ensure the visual system updates properly with the hourly tick system and on-demand
   - Implement performance optimizations: sprite batching, minimal redraws, memory management

File/Module Structure:
- /src/visuals/
  - OverlayManager.ts
  - SpriteRegistry.ts
  - DamageVisualSystem.ts
  - DamageEventManager.ts
  - types.ts (shared types/enums)
- /assets/overlays/
- /assets/sprites/

The implementation should prioritize performance, using sprite batching and efficient rendering techniques to minimize impact on frame rate, especially when many buildings are visible.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing for this visual representation system should be comprehensive and include:

1. Unit Testing:
   - Verify that damage state changes correctly trigger the appropriate visual changes
   - Test the overlay system with various combinations of damage types
   - Ensure sprite switching occurs at the correct damage thresholds
   - Validate that visual feedback events trigger and display correctly
   - Test OverlayManager and SpriteRegistry functionality independently
   - Verify DamageEventManager properly queues and processes visual events

2. Integration Testing:
   - Confirm proper integration with the core damage system (Task #422)
   - Verify that module-specific damage (Task #423) is correctly visualized
   - Test that hourly tick updates properly refresh the visual state
   - Ensure damage events from multiple sources are all visually represented
   - Validate the complete pipeline from damage event to visual representation

3. Performance Testing:
   - Measure frame rate impact with various numbers of damaged buildings on screen
   - Test memory usage with large numbers of buildings and damage states
   - Verify sprite caching is working effectively
   - Benchmark sprite batching and redraw optimizations

4. Visual Verification:
   - Create a test scene with buildings in various damage states for side-by-side comparison
   - Implement a debug mode that displays numerical damage values alongside visual representations
   - Record before/after screenshots for each damage state transition
   - Verify correct Z-ordering and overlay positioning across different building types

5. Playtesting Feedback:
   - Conduct focused playtesting sessions specifically evaluating the clarity of damage feedback
   - Create a survey for playtesters to rate how intuitive the damage visualization is
   - Gather feedback on whether damage progression feels appropriate and noticeable

The task will be considered complete when all tests pass, performance meets targets (less than 5% frame rate impact with 50+ buildings), and playtester feedback confirms the damage visualization is clear and intuitive.

tasks.title: Task #443: Implement Settlement Generation System for World Building
tasks.description: Develop a comprehensive settlement generation system that creates varied and realistic settlements with different classifications, layouts, building rules, and infrastructure to support the game's world generation pipeline.
tasks.details:
The settlement generation system should include the following components:

1. Settlement Classification Module:
   - Implement three distinct settlement types (VILLAGE/TOWN/CITY) with appropriate scaling factors
   - Each classification should have unique characteristics affecting size, population, building density, and available services
   - Create transition rules for settlements to evolve between classifications based on growth parameters

2. Layout Pattern Implementation:
   - Develop algorithms for four distinct layout patterns: GRID, CLUSTERED, RADIAL, and ORGANIC
   - Each pattern should influence road placement, building orientation, and district formation
   - Implement pattern blending for realistic transitions between different layout sections
   - Include historical growth simulation to create authentic-looking settlements that appear to have developed over time

3. Building Placement System:
   - Create rules for special building placement (temples, town halls, markets, etc.) based on settlement type and layout
   - Implement zoning system for residential, commercial, industrial, and special purpose areas
   - Develop building density gradients that typically decrease from center to periphery
   - Include rules for landmark placement at strategic locations

4. POI (Points of Interest) Integration:
   - Connect with existing POI system to place quest-relevant locations within settlements
   - Implement POI distribution algorithms based on settlement size and type
   - Create relationship rules between POIs and surrounding buildings/infrastructure
   - Ensure POIs are accessible via the road network

5. Population Density Calculations:
   - Develop formulas to calculate realistic population distribution within settlements
   - Create visualization tools for population heat maps during development
   - Implement population-based resource consumption and production metrics
   - Ensure population density affects building types and infrastructure needs

6. Thematic Element Application:
   - Create a system to apply cultural, geographical, and historical themes to settlements
   - Implement visual style variations based on themes (architecture, colors, materials)
   - Develop theme-specific building and decoration placement rules
   - Allow for mixed themes in border regions or trading hubs

7. Road Network Generation:
   - Implement algorithms for generating realistic road networks based on layout patterns
   - Create hierarchy of roads (main roads, side streets, alleys) with appropriate widths and properties
   - Ensure connectivity between all buildings and POIs
   - Develop natural pathfinding for organic road patterns that follow terrain

8. Integration with Existing Systems:
   - Connect with terrain generation to ensure settlements adapt to landscape features
   - Interface with the material system (Task #440) for appropriate building construction
   - Utilize the physics system (Task #441) for structural integrity validation
   - Implement performance optimizations as outlined in Task #442

The system should be modular and data-driven, allowing designers to create new settlement templates and rules without code changes. All parameters should be exposed through configuration files for easy tuning.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing for the Settlement Generation System will involve multiple stages:

1. Unit Testing:
   - Create automated tests for each module (classification, layout, building placement, etc.)
   - Verify that each algorithm produces expected outputs for given inputs
   - Test edge cases such as extremely small or large settlements
   - Validate that all required components are generated for each settlement type

2. Integration Testing:
   - Test the settlement system's integration with terrain generation
   - Verify proper connections with the POI system
   - Ensure material system integration works correctly for building construction
   - Validate physics system interaction for structural integrity

3. Performance Testing:
   - Benchmark generation times for different settlement sizes and complexities
   - Profile memory usage during generation process
   - Identify and optimize bottlenecks in the generation pipeline
   - Verify the system meets performance targets on minimum spec hardware

4. Visual Inspection:
   - Create a visualization tool to review generated settlements in both 2D and 3D views
   - Compare generated settlements against reference designs for aesthetic quality
   - Verify that different layout patterns produce visually distinct results
   - Check that thematic elements are correctly applied and visually coherent

5. Procedural Validation:
   - Generate 100+ random settlements and analyze the results for patterns or issues
   - Verify statistical distribution of features matches design expectations
   - Check for unrealistic or problematic generations (disconnected areas, inaccessible buildings)
   - Validate that population density calculations produce realistic results

6. Designer Review:
   - Conduct structured review sessions with level designers and world builders
   - Gather feedback on usability of the system and quality of outputs
   - Test designer ability to customize settlement parameters effectively
   - Document any requested improvements or additional features

7. Playability Testing:
   - Verify player navigation through generated settlements is intuitive
   - Test NPC pathfinding within settlement road networks
   - Ensure all POIs are discoverable and accessible
   - Check performance during gameplay in densely populated settlements

Success criteria include: settlements generate within performance budgets, visual quality meets artistic standards, all functional requirements are implemented, and the system integrates properly with existing world generation pipeline.

tasks.title: Task #447: Implement World Generation Integration with Building System
tasks.description: Develop a comprehensive integration between the building system and world generation that handles terrain adaptation, placement rules, customization hooks, and material systems to enable buildings to properly interact with procedurally generated environments.
tasks.details:
The implementation should focus on the following key components:

1. Terrain Adaptation System:
   - Create algorithms to adapt building foundations to varying terrain heights and slopes
   - Implement automatic stair/ramp generation for entrances on uneven terrain
   - Develop structural integrity calculations based on terrain type and stability
   - Handle edge cases like water boundaries, cliffs, and steep inclines

2. Placement Rule Engine:
   - Design a rule-based system for building placement constraints by biome type
   - Implement resource proximity requirements (e.g., buildings near water, forests, minerals)
   - Create population density controls to prevent overcrowding
   - Develop conflict resolution for overlapping placement requirements

3. Customization Framework:
   - Build an extensible hook system allowing runtime modification of building generation
   - Implement parameter-driven generation with sensible defaults
   - Create a clean API for future extensions and modifications
   - Design serializable configuration objects for saving/loading customizations

4. Style and Material Integration:
   - Develop a material selection system based on biome and available resources
   - Implement style definitions that adapt to world regions
   - Create texture and model variation based on environmental factors
   - Build a coherent visual language that maintains consistency while allowing variation

5. Performance Optimization:
   - Implement chunked generation to avoid performance spikes
   - Create LOD (Level of Detail) systems for distant buildings
   - Optimize memory usage for large-scale world generation
   - Implement caching mechanisms for frequently accessed building templates

The system must be designed with future extensibility in mind, allowing for new building types, biomes, and generation rules without requiring significant refactoring.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing will be conducted through a multi-phase approach:

1. Unit Testing:
   - Create automated tests for each component (terrain adaptation, placement rules, etc.)
   - Verify correct behavior with edge cases (extreme slopes, resource scarcity, etc.)
   - Test performance with varying world sizes and building densities
   - Validate memory usage patterns during extended generation sessions

2. Integration Testing:
   - Test the building system with different world generation seeds
   - Verify proper integration with existing biome and terrain systems
   - Ensure consistent behavior across different hardware configurations

3. Visual Verification:

   - Capture screenshots for visual regression testing

4. Playtest Preparation:
   - Create a dedicated test level with diverse terrain and building scenarios
   - Develop metrics collection for building placement success rates
   - Implement feedback mechanisms for testers to report issues
   - Prepare a comprehensive test plan for the upcoming playtest sessions

5. Performance Benchmarking:

   - Profile memory usage during extended generation sessions
   - Test scalability with increasing numbers of buildings
   - Verify load times for saved worlds with complex building-terrain interactions

Success criteria include: buildings properly adapting to terrain in all biomes, consistent style and material application, performance within acceptable parameters (generation of a standard world in under 30 seconds), and no visual glitches at building-terrain boundaries.

subtasks.title: Optimize Performance for Large-Scale Generation
subtasks.description: Implement performance optimizations to ensure efficient building generation across large world areas without causing frame rate drops or memory issues.
subtasks.details:
Implement chunked generation with prioritization based on player proximity. Create a multi-threaded building generation pipeline. Develop LOD (Level of Detail) systems for distant buildings. Optimize memory usage with object pooling for building components. Implement caching mechanisms for frequently accessed building templates and generation results. Add performance monitoring tools to identify bottlenecks.
<info added on 2025-05-16T00:09:32.216Z>

Optimize memory usage with object pooling for building components. Implement caching mechanisms for frequently accessed building templates and generation results. Add performance monitoring tools to identify bottlenecks.

Implementation Plan for Performance Optimization:

1. Chunked Generation:
- Refactor building generation to operate in spatial chunks (16x16 cells)
- Implement priority queue based on player/camera proximity
- Add throttling mechanism for distant chunks to prevent frame rate spikes
- Create ChunkManager class to handle chunk lifecycle and state management

2. Multi-threaded Pipeline:
- Implement web workers/worker threads for offloading generation tasks
- Design thread-safe data access patterns for shared resources
- Create job queue system for managing chunk generation tasks
- Add message passing interface between main thread and workers

3. Level of Detail (LOD) System:
- Define 4 LOD levels (full detail, simplified, placeholder, none)
- Create distance-based LOD selection algorithm
- Implement smooth LOD transitions to prevent popping
- Integrate LOD system with rendering and generation pipelines

4. Memory Optimization:
- Implement object pooling for common building components
- Create reuse strategy for building objects during chunk cycling
- Add memory usage tracking and reporting
- Optimize texture and mesh memory usage for distant buildings

5. Caching Mechanisms:
- Implement LRU cache for building templates and generation results
- Create cache invalidation system for template/region data changes
- Add cache hit/miss metrics for performance tuning
- Optimize cache size based on available system memory

6. Performance Monitoring:
- Add instrumentation for per-chunk generation timing
- Implement memory usage tracking per region/chunk
- Create visualization tools for performance metrics
- Add configurable logging for performance data

Key files to update:
- src/worldgen/region/ProceduralRegionGenerator.ts
- src/worldgen/region/ChunkManager.ts (new)
- src/worldgen/region/LODSystem.ts (new)
- src/worldgen/region/BuildingCache.ts (new)
- src/worldgen/region/PerformanceMonitor.ts (new)

tasks.title: Task #448: Implement Enhanced Building Interface and Customization Features
tasks.description: Develop and implement an improved building system user interface with advanced customization options including visual previews, undo/redo functionality, improved placement guides, and various other features to enhance user experience before playtesting begins.
tasks.details:

   - Implement alignment guides for precise positioning relative to existing structures
   - Add distance indicators and measurement tools

5. Material Property Tooltips:
   - Create an information system displaying material properties on hover
   - Include durability, cost, aesthetic values, and special properties
   - Support comparison between different materials

6. Construction Time Estimates:
   - Implement an algorithm to calculate realistic construction times
   - Factor in material types, structure complexity, and builder skill levels
   - Display time estimates during the planning phase

7. Regional Building Styles:
   - Create a system for region-specific architectural templates
   - Include appropriate material palettes for different biomes/regions
   - Support style mixing and customization

8. Advanced Material Combinations:
   - Implement a system for combining materials for composite effects
   - Support layering and mixing of materials with visual feedback
   - Include performance considerations for complex material combinations

9. Blueprint System:
   - Develop save/load functionality for building designs
   - Implement sharing capabilities between players
   - Create a categorization and tagging system for blueprints

10. Decoration Options:
    - Add a comprehensive decoration placement system
    - Support scaling, rotation, and precise positioning of decorative elements
    - Implement categories and filtering for decoration items

tasks.testStrategy:

1. Unit Testing:

<info added on 2025-05-16T01:08:02.860Z>
The POI Evolution Data Model will implement a temporal database approach to track the complete lifecycle of Points of Interest. The model consists of the following key entities:

1. Core Entity Structure:
   - poi: Base table containing immutable identifier and core POI properties
   - poi_state: Temporal state table with valid_from/valid_to timestamps implementing bitemporal modeling
   - poi_transition: Records state changes with references to before/after states
   - poi_history: Audit log capturing all modifications with metadata

2. Schema Design Details:
   - Use surrogate primary keys (auto-incrementing integers) for all tables
   - Implement foreign key constraints to maintain referential integrity
   - Store complex/variable state data in JSONB fields for flexibility
   - Include standard audit fields (created_at, updated_at, created_by, updated_by)
   - Add version numbering for optimistic concurrency control

3. Indexing Strategy:
   - Primary B-tree indexes on all ID fields
   - Composite indexes on (poi_id, valid_from, valid_to) for temporal queries
   - Indexes on event_type and triggered_at for filtering transitions
   - Consider partial indexes for current state queries (where valid_to IS NULL)
   - Add GIN indexes for JSONB fields if complex querying is needed

4. Query Optimization:
   - Optimize for common access patterns:
     * Current state retrieval (most frequent)
     * Point-in-time historical state lookup
     * Transition history for a specific POI
     * Aggregate analysis across POIs
   - Consider materialized views for frequently accessed current states

5. Data Integrity Measures:
   - Implement triggers to maintain valid_from/valid_to consistency
   - Ensure non-overlapping time periods for a given POI's states
   - Validate transitions for logical consistency
   - Prevent deletion of historical records (implement soft deletion if needed)

6. Extensibility Considerations:
   - Design schema to accommodate future metadata additions
   - Document extension points for new POI properties or state attributes
   - Plan for schema versioning to handle evolution of the data model itself
</info added on 2025-05-16T01:08:02.860Z>
<info added on 2025-05-16T01:08:43.077Z>
The POI Evolution Data Model will be implemented using a PostgreSQL database with the following schema design:

1. Core Tables:
   - poi: Base table with immutable identifiers and core properties
   - poi_state: Temporal state table implementing bitemporal modeling
   - poi_transition: Records state changes with references to before/after states
   - poi_history: Audit log capturing all modifications with metadata

2. SQL DDL Implementation:
   ```sql
   -- Table: poi (base POI entity)
   CREATE TABLE poi (
       id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
       name TEXT NOT NULL,
       type TEXT NOT NULL,
       location GEOGRAPHY, -- or geometry, depending on GIS needs
       created_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
       created_by TEXT,
       updated_at TIMESTAMPTZ,
       updated_by TEXT
   );

   -- Table: poi_state (temporal state records)
   CREATE TABLE poi_state (
       id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
       poi_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES poi(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
       state_data JSONB NOT NULL, -- flexible state representation
       valid_from TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL,
       valid_to TIMESTAMPTZ,
       version INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 1,
       created_at TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
       created_by TEXT,
       CONSTRAINT poi_state_no_overlap CHECK (valid_to IS NULL OR valid_to > valid_from)
   );
   CREATE INDEX idx_poi_state_poiid_valid ON poi_state (poi_id, valid_from, valid_to);
   CREATE INDEX idx_poi_state_current ON poi_state (poi_id) WHERE valid_to IS NULL;
   CREATE INDEX idx_poi_state_state_data ON poi_state USING GIN (state_data);

   -- Table: poi_transition (state transitions)
   CREATE TABLE poi_transition (
       id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
       poi_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES poi(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
       from_state_id INTEGER REFERENCES poi_state(id),
   ```

subtasks.title: Evaluate and Select Storage Technologies
subtasks.description: Research, evaluate, and select the optimal storage technologies for the POI evolution data based on performance, scalability, and reliability requirements.
subtasks.details:
Conduct a comparative analysis of storage options including relational databases (PostgreSQL, MySQL), NoSQL solutions (MongoDB, Cassandra), and time-series databases. Consider hybrid approaches that use different technologies for different data access patterns. Create a decision matrix with criteria including query performance, write throughput, scalability, operational complexity, and cost. Produce a detailed recommendation document with benchmarks and rationale for the selected technologies.
<info added on 2025-05-16T01:09:25.316Z>
After thorough analysis of storage options for the POI evolution history, we've completed a comprehensive evaluation based on our specific requirements. 

Our key requirements included high write throughput for POI state changes, efficient historical and current state queries, strong consistency and referential integrity, schema extensibility, mature operational capabilities, and cost-effectiveness.

We evaluated three main categories of storage technologies:

1. Relational Databases (PostgreSQL, MySQL):
   - PostgreSQL offers ACID compliance, strong schema support, advanced indexing, JSONB for flexible data, robust backup/restore, partitioning, materialized views, triggers, and PostGIS for spatial data
   - Write scaling requires careful partitioning/sharding strategies for very high volumes

2. NoSQL Solutions (MongoDB, Cassandra):
   - Provide schema flexibility and horizontal scaling with high write throughput (especially Cassandra)
   - However, they offer weaker consistency guarantees, less robust complex query support, limited referential integrity, and increased operational complexity

3. Time-Series Databases (TimescaleDB, InfluxDB):
   - Optimized for time-based data and efficient historical queries
   - Less suitable for complex entity relationships and relational joins

Our decision matrix evaluated these options across multiple criteria:
- Query Performance: PostgreSQL with proper partitioning, indexing, and materialized views provides excellent performance for both current and historical queries
- Write Throughput: PostgreSQL offers sufficient throughput for our expected volumes, with scaling options via partitioning and connection pooling
- Consistency & Integrity: PostgreSQL provides industry-standard strong consistency and referential integrity
- Extensibility: PostgreSQL supports JSONB for flexible data, schema evolution capabilities, and numerous extensions
- Operational Maturity: PostgreSQL has a mature ecosystem for backup, monitoring, and recovery
- Cost: PostgreSQL is open-source with no licensing fees

Based on this evaluation, we've selected PostgreSQL as our primary storage technology for the POI evolution history. For potential future scaling needs with extremely high write volumes or cold data archiving, we may consider supplementing with TimescaleDB (a PostgreSQL extension) or object storage for raw event logs.

This decision aligns with industry best practices for managing transactional, temporal, and spatial data in modern applications. We'll proceed with implementing the data access layer and repository pattern using PostgreSQL as our backend.

tasks.title: Task #469: Integrate GPT-Driven Dynamic Dialogue System with Context Management
tasks.description: Replace the traditional branching dialogue system with a GPT-driven dynamic dialogue generation system, including conversation context management and a caching mechanism for common phrases to optimize API usage.
tasks.details:
This task involves several key components:

1. **GPT Integration**:
   - Implement API client for connecting to OpenAI's GPT service
   - Create a dialogue generation service that formats prompts with appropriate context
   - Develop fallback mechanisms for handling API failures or timeouts
   - Implement rate limiting and token usage monitoring

2. **Context Management System**:
   - Design a conversation history data structure that tracks previous exchanges
   - Implement context windowing to manage token limits (sliding window approach)
   - Create relevance scoring to prioritize important context elements
   - Develop a system to extract and persist key information from conversations

3. **Caching System** (Medium Priority):
   - Design a caching layer for common phrases and responses
   - Implement cache invalidation strategies
   - Create analytics to identify frequently generated content
   - Develop a pre-warming system for anticipated dialogue paths

4. **Integration with Existing Systems**:
   - Refactor the Interaction System to use the new dialogue generation
   - Update UI components to handle dynamic response timing
   - Modify existing dialogue triggers to work with the new system
   - Ensure compatibility with the recently implemented Redux-style state management (Task #468)

5. **Configuration and Tuning**:
   - Create configuration options for response style, tone, and character personalities
   - Implement prompt templates for different conversation scenarios
   - Develop tools for fine-tuning and adjusting dialogue generation parameters

Implementation should prioritize the core GPT integration and context management components first to enable play-testing, with the caching system implemented before launch but at a lower priority.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing will be conducted in multiple phases:

1. **Unit Testing**:
   - Test GPT API client with mock responses
   - Verify context management functions correctly track and prioritize conversation history
   - Validate caching system correctly stores and retrieves responses
   - Ensure fallback mechanisms work when API is unavailable

2. **Integration Testing**:
   - Verify dialogue system integrates properly with the Redux-style state management
   - Test conversation flow across multiple interactions to ensure context is maintained
   - Validate that UI components correctly display dynamic responses
   - Measure and optimize response times across different dialogue scenarios

3. **Performance Testing**:
   - Benchmark API usage and costs under various load conditions
   - Measure cache hit rates and effectiveness
   - Test system performance with simulated concurrent users
   - Verify token usage stays within expected limits

4. **Playtest Validation**:
   - Conduct structured playtests focusing on dialogue naturalness and coherence
   - Compare player satisfaction metrics between old and new dialogue systems
   - Gather feedback on conversation flow and context awareness
   - Identify and address any uncanny valley effects in AI-generated dialogue

5. **Regression Testing**:
   - Ensure existing dialogue-dependent game mechanics still function correctly
   - Verify that saved games and state persistence work with the new system
   - Test edge cases where context might be lost or corrupted

Success criteria include: response generation under 2 seconds, 95% context coherence across 10+ conversation turns, 30% reduction in API calls through caching, and positive playtest feedback on dialogue naturalness.

5. **Redux Integration**: Integrate interruption state into the central Redux-style state management. Define actions, reducers, and selectors for interruption state. Ensure all state changes are serializable and compatible with time-travel debugging.

6. **Timestamps and Metadata**: Each interruption state object will include a timestamp, triggering event, and optional metadata (e.g., error details, user ID). This will aid in debugging and analytics.

Based on the implementation progress update, I've identified the key components and integration points between the Interaction System and POI Evolution System. The architecture documentation will focus on the following structure:

1. System Roles and Responsibilities:
   - The Interaction System manages all NPC interactions (NPC-to-NPC and NPC-to-environment), handling complex social behaviors including dialogue, trade, mentoring, conflict resolution, social bonding, information sharing, group decisions, negotiation, deception, cooperation, and competition. It integrates with multiple subsystems including DialogueManager, EmotionSystem, ReputationSystem, MemoryManager, GroupFormationSystem, and EconomicAgentSystem.
   
   - The POI Evolution System manages the dynamic evolution of Points of Interest based on game events and interactions. It implements rule-based evolution with multiple trigger types (time-based, event-based, and interaction-based) and emits events (notably 'poi:evolved') to signal state changes to other systems. It primarily integrates with the POIManager and relies on an event-driven architecture for cross-system communication.

2. Integration Architecture:
   - The primary integration mechanism is the central EventBus, where the POI Evolution System emits 'poi:evolved' events that can be consumed by the Interaction System and other game systems.
   - The Interaction System can indirectly trigger POI evolution by causing interactions that meet evolution rule conditions.
   - Both systems follow a publish-subscribe pattern, enabling decoupled, asynchronous communication through standardized event payloads.

3. Technical Implementation:
   - Both systems are built on TypeScript/Node.js backend.
   - The architecture follows an event-driven design using a custom in-process EventBus (with potential for replacement with RabbitMQ/Kafka for distributed deployments).
   - Shared data models and TypeScript interfaces ensure type safety across system boundaries.
   - Key shared resources include the EventBus, POIManager, and typed event interfaces (POIEvents, InteractionContext, etc.).

The architecture diagram will visualize these components, showing the event flow between systems and highlighting the decoupled nature of the integration. UI Communication Specification for Progression-Locked Interactions:

Visual Indicators:
- Grayed-out (desaturated) interaction options for unavailable/locked content
- Lock icon overlay on locked interactions
- Color coding: green (available), yellow (nearly available), red/gray (locked)

- If multiple requirements, list all with checkmarks () for met and crosses () for unmet
- For temporary locks (e.g., event ended), show reason ("Event expired")

Dynamic UI Elements:
- UI updates in real-time as progression changes (e.g., after leveling up, completing a quest)
- Notification banner or toast when a previously locked interaction becomes available
- Optional sound cue for major unlocks

Accessibility:
- All color indicators must have shape/icon redundancy for colorblind users
- Tooltips and lock icons must be screen-reader accessible (ARIA labels, descriptive text)
- Sufficient contrast for all UI elements

Wireframe/Mockup Guidelines:
- Dialogue menu: locked options grayed out with lock icon, tooltip on hover
- Inventory: locked vendor items show lock icon and tooltip
- World interaction: locked objects display lock icon and requirement tooltip on approach
- UI should be modular to support new interaction types and requirements

Feedback Mechanisms:
- Animation and/or sound when an interaction unlocks
- Visual highlight or pulse for newly available options
- Optional notification log for recent unlocks

All UI elements and behaviors should be documented in a design system for consistency and future extensibility. These guidelines ensure players always understand why an interaction is locked and what is needed to unlock it, supporting both usability and engagement.

tasks.title: Task #475: Define Performance Targets for Concurrent Interactions in the Interaction System
tasks.description: Establish clear performance benchmarks for the Interaction System under concurrent load, including maximum supported concurrent sessions, latency goals, and resource usage limits to ensure optimal performance during play-testing.
tasks.details:
This task requires a comprehensive analysis and definition of performance targets for the Interaction System when handling multiple concurrent interactions. The developer should:

1. Analyze the expected user interaction patterns and peak usage scenarios
2. Define the maximum number of concurrent interaction sessions the system must support without degradation
3. Establish acceptable latency thresholds for different interaction types (e.g., simple vs. complex interactions)
4. Set memory usage limits per interaction and for the overall system
5. Define CPU utilization targets under various load conditions
6. Establish network bandwidth requirements for multiplayer scenarios
7. Document how performance targets may vary across different platforms (PC, console, mobile)
8. Create a performance budget that allocates resources between the Interaction System and other game systems
9. Define graceful degradation strategies when system approaches resource limits
10. Establish monitoring requirements to track performance metrics during play-testing
11. Consider how the Interaction System's performance relates to previously documented dependencies with Building Modification/Construction and POI Evolution Systems
12. Document any performance implications related to character progression mechanics

The performance targets should be realistic, measurable, and aligned with the overall game performance requirements. The documentation should be detailed enough to guide implementation and testing efforts.
tasks.testStrategy:
The testing strategy for verifying performance targets should include:

1. Develop automated load testing scripts that simulate concurrent interactions at various scales
2. Create synthetic user profiles that mimic expected player behavior patterns
3. Implement performance monitoring tools to capture metrics during testing:
   - Response time/latency measurements for each interaction type
   - Memory usage tracking (peak and average)
   - CPU utilization monitoring
   - Network bandwidth consumption
   - Thread utilization and contention metrics
4. Conduct incremental load tests starting from minimal concurrent sessions and gradually increasing to beyond target maximums
5. Perform sustained load tests at target concurrent session counts for extended periods (minimum 4-8 hours)
6. Test performance under various game states and scenarios (e.g., early game vs. late game content)
7. Verify performance across all target platforms and hardware configurations
8. Test integration points with dependent systems (Building Modification, POI Evolution) under concurrent load
9. Document performance bottlenecks and optimization opportunities
10. Validate graceful degradation mechanisms when system exceeds defined limits
11. Conduct play-testing sessions with real users while monitoring performance metrics
12. Compare test results against defined performance targets and document any deviations
13. Create performance regression tests to ensure future changes don't negatively impact established targets

The testing should produce comprehensive performance reports with visualizations of key metrics that can be used to validate the defined performance targets have been met.

tasks.details:

1. Create a centralized emotion definition framework that:
   - Defines a core set of base emotions with extensible properties
   - Supports hierarchical relationships between simple and complex emotions
   - Includes metadata for context-appropriate toggling (performance vs. fidelity)
   - Provides clear interfaces for all systems that consume emotion data

2. Develop a bidirectional mapping system that:
   - Translates between visual representations (facial expressions, animations)
   - Maps to/from behavioral manifestations (voice tone, gestures, posture)
   - Connects with internal emotional states (memory impact, decision influence)
   - Ensures all three layers remain synchronized during runtime

3. Implement a context-aware toggling mechanism that:
   - Dynamically adjusts emotion processing based on system load
   - Prioritizes critical emotional expressions in high-demand scenarios
   - Gracefully degrades complexity when performance requires it
   - Logs any forced simplifications for debugging purposes

4. Refactor existing emotion-related code to:
   - Remove redundant implementations across different systems
   - Consolidate similar functionality into the unified model
   - Update all dependent systems to use the new architecture
   - Maintain backward compatibility where absolutely necessary

5. Create a comprehensive API documentation for the new emotion system that clearly explains:
   - How to define new emotions within the framework
   - The mapping process between different emotional representations
   - Performance considerations and toggling mechanisms
   - Integration points with other systems (dialogue, memory, etc.)

3. Dynamic Simulation Fidelity:

   - Create configuration parameters for minimum acceptable fidelity levels

   - Measure CPU usage, memory consumption, and frame rates in controlled test scenarios
   - Create automated performance tests that can be run in CI/CD pipeline

2. Functional Testing:
   - Verify that NPCs transition correctly between different LOD levels
   - Confirm that event-driven updates maintain gameplay consistency
   - Test edge cases where many NPCs might need to update simultaneously
   - Validate that crowd models accurately represent expected behaviors

3. Integration Testing:
   - Ensure compatibility with Emotion API by testing emotional state propagation
   - Verify reputation system interactions work correctly at all LOD levels
   - Test interactions between player and NPCs across LOD boundaries

4. Scalability Testing:

tasks.title: Task #490: Reputation System Integration Audit and Documentation
tasks.description: Conduct a comprehensive audit and create detailed documentation of all integration points between the reputation system and other game systems (dialogue, quest, combat, AI, economy, etc.) to ensure robust, clearly defined interfaces for play-testing.
tasks.details:
This task requires a systematic approach to mapping all integration points between the reputation system and other game systems:

1. Identify all systems that interact with the reputation system:
   - Dialogue system (how reputation affects conversation options and NPC responses)
   - Quest system (how reputation gates quests or influences outcomes)
   - Combat system (how reputation affects aggression, difficulty scaling, or faction behaviors)
   - AI behavior system (how reputation influences NPC decision-making and reactions)
   - Economy system (how reputation affects prices, availability of goods/services)
   - Faction system (how reputation propagates through related groups)
   - Any other systems with reputation dependencies

2. For each integration point, document:
   - Direction of data flow (which system initiates the interaction)
   - Data structures and types being passed
   - Frequency of updates (real-time, event-based, periodic)
   - Error handling and fallback behaviors
   - Performance considerations (any potential bottlenecks)
   - Edge cases and boundary conditions

3. Create sequence diagrams for complex interactions showing the flow of reputation data across multiple systems.

4. Develop a comprehensive API reference document detailing all public methods, events, and data structures used for reputation system integration.

5. Review existing code to ensure all integrations follow established patterns and best practices.

6. Identify any undocumented or ad-hoc integrations that need formalization.

7. Ensure proper logging is implemented at all integration points to facilitate debugging during play-testing.

8. Create a centralized registry of all reputation-affecting events and their magnitudes across all systems.

This task builds upon Task #487 (Comprehensive Audit of Reputation-Affecting Actions) but focuses specifically on the technical integration points rather than the design-level actions and events.
tasks.testStrategy:
The completion of this task should be verified through the following steps:

1. Documentation Review:
   - Technical review of all produced documentation by leads from each integrated system
   - Verification that all known integration points are captured
   - Confirmation that API references are accurate and complete

2. Code Validation:
   - Static analysis to identify all code paths that reference the reputation system
   - Compare findings against documented integration points to ensure completeness
   - Verify that proper error handling exists at all integration points

3. Integration Testing:
   - Develop and execute test cases for each documented integration point
   - Create automated tests that verify data consistency across system boundaries
   - Perform boundary testing with extreme reputation values to ensure robust handling

4. Play-testing Scenarios:
   - Create specific play-testing scenarios designed to exercise each integration point
   - Provide play-testers with a checklist of reputation-related interactions to verify
   - Collect and analyze logs from play-testing sessions to identify any undocumented interactions

5. Regression Testing:
   - Ensure that any changes made during the audit don't disrupt existing functionality
   - Verify that reputation changes propagate correctly through all connected systems

6. Documentation Usability Testing:
   - Have developers unfamiliar with the reputation system attempt to use the documentation to implement a new integration
   - Gather feedback on clarity and completeness of documentation

7. Final Validation:
   - Present findings in a cross-team review meeting
   - Obtain sign-off from technical leads of all integrated systems

tasks.title: Task #491: Party Leadership Requirement Audit and Documentation
tasks.description: Conduct a comprehensive audit of the codebase to identify and document all instances where party leadership logic is implemented, and ensure that every party always has a designated leader (player or NPC) with clear documentation in system requirements and user guides.
tasks.details:
This task requires a thorough review of the entire codebase to identify all systems and components that interact with or depend on party leadership mechanics. The implementation should include:

1. Code Audit:
   - Identify all classes, methods, and functions that reference party leadership
   - Document the current implementation of leadership assignment and transfer
   - Map dependencies between party leadership and other systems (combat, dialogue, quest progression, etc.)
   - Identify edge cases where leadership might be undefined (party member death, disconnection, etc.)

2. System Enhancements:
   - Implement failsafe mechanisms to ensure a party always has a leader
   - Create automatic leadership transfer protocols when a leader becomes unavailable
   - Develop clear rules for leadership assignment priority (player over NPC, highest level character, etc.)
   - Add logging and error reporting for any detected leadership gaps

3. Documentation Updates:
   - Update system requirements documentation with clear leadership rules
   - Create technical documentation for developers explaining leadership implementation
   - Update user-facing documentation to explain leadership mechanics to players
   - Document leadership transfer scenarios and their gameplay implications

4. Cross-System Integration:
   - Ensure consistent leadership references across dialogue, quest, and combat systems
   - Verify that AI systems properly recognize and respond to party leadership
   - Confirm that UI elements correctly display leadership status
   - Check that save/load systems properly preserve leadership state

This task should result in a robust, well-documented leadership system that prevents any scenario where a party could exist without a designated leader.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing for this task should be comprehensive and include:

1. Static Code Analysis:
   - Use code scanning tools to identify all references to party leadership
   - Verify that all identified code paths have proper error handling
   - Confirm that leadership assignment logic is consistent across the codebase

2. Unit Testing:
   - Create unit tests for all leadership assignment and transfer functions
   - Test edge cases including leader disconnection, death, or removal from party
   - Verify automatic leadership assignment works correctly in all scenarios

3. Integration Testing:
   - Test leadership mechanics across all integrated systems (combat, dialogue, quests)

   - Verify leadership UI indicators update correctly in all scenarios

5. Documentation Verification:

6. Regression Testing:
   - Ensure leadership changes don't negatively impact existing gameplay systems
   - Verify performance is not degraded by new leadership validation checks

Success criteria: No party can exist without a designated leader at any point during gameplay, all documentation clearly explains leadership mechanics, and all systems correctly recognize and respond to the designated party leader.

tasks.title: Task #493: Party Disbanding Trigger Audit and Documentation
tasks.description: Review, document, and verify all party disbanding triggers in the codebase, ensuring comprehensive coverage of all dissolution scenarios while clarifying that guild organizations use separate persistence mechanisms.
tasks.details:
This task requires a thorough code review to identify and document all mechanisms that can trigger party disbanding. The developer should:

1. Identify all code paths that can lead to party disbanding, including:
   - Member-initiated disbanding (all members leaving)
   - Leader-initiated disbanding (explicit disband command)
   - System-triggered disbanding (inactivity timers, quest completion, etc.)
   - Edge cases (leader disconnection, server crashes, etc.)

2. Create a comprehensive document that:
   - Maps each disbanding trigger to its location in the codebase
   - Describes the exact conditions that activate each trigger
   - Explains the sequence of events during disbanding (notifications, inventory handling, etc.)
   - Clarifies that persistent organizations (guilds) operate under different rules
   - Identifies any inconsistencies or potential bugs in the current implementation

3. Verify that all disbanding scenarios properly:
   - Clean up party-related data structures
   - Update player states correctly
   - Send appropriate notifications to affected players
   - Handle edge cases gracefully

4. Explicitly document that guild organizations:
   - Are not subject to the same disbanding rules as parties
   - Have their own persistence mechanisms
   - Should not be affected by party disbanding logic

The documentation should be structured in a way that helps future developers understand the complete lifecycle of parties, with special focus on the termination conditions.
tasks.testStrategy:
To verify this task has been completed successfully:

1. Code Review Verification:
   - Have at least two senior developers review the documentation against the codebase
   - Confirm all party disbanding triggers are accurately identified and documented
   - Verify no disbanding scenarios are missing from the documentation

2. Functional Testing:
   - Create test cases for each identified disbanding trigger
   - Test each disbanding scenario in a development environment:
     * Create a party and have all members leave one by one
     * Have a party leader use the disband command
     * Trigger system-based disbanding (simulate inactivity timeouts, complete relevant quests)
     * Test edge cases like leader disconnection or server restarts
   - Verify that in each case, the party disbands correctly and all cleanup operations execute properly

3. Guild Separation Testing:
   - Create a guild and verify that none of the party disbanding triggers affect it
   - Document the separation of concerns between party and guild systems

4. Documentation Quality Check:
   - Ensure the documentation is clear, comprehensive, and follows project standards
   - Verify that the documentation includes diagrams or flowcharts showing the disbanding logic
   - Confirm the documentation is accessible in the project's knowledge base

5. Edge Case Validation:
   - Test scenarios where disbanding might conflict with other operations (combat, trading, etc.)
   - Verify proper handling of disbanding during critical game operations

The task is complete when all disbanding triggers are documented, tested, and the separation between parties and guilds is clearly established in both code and documentation.

tasks.title: Task #494: Implement Race Condition Handling for Party Join/Leave Operations
tasks.description: Develop and implement a robust mechanism to handle simultaneous join/leave requests and race conditions in party logic, ensuring consistent party state through appropriate locking or queuing mechanisms.
tasks.details:
This task requires implementing a concurrency control system for party membership operations to prevent data inconsistencies when multiple operations occur simultaneously. The developer should:

1. Analyze the current party join/leave implementation to identify potential race conditions and concurrency issues.
2. Design a solution using either:
   - Distributed locking mechanism (e.g., Redis-based locks, database locks)
   - Queue-based approach where operations are processed sequentially
   - Optimistic concurrency control with version checking
3. Implement the chosen solution with appropriate error handling and retry logic.
4. Add logging for all party state transitions to aid debugging.
5. Create clear documentation explaining:
   - The concurrency issues that were addressed
   - The technical approach chosen and rationale
   - How the solution integrates with existing party management code
   - Any performance considerations or trade-offs made
6. Update relevant code sections including:
   - Party join handler
   - Party leave/kick handler
   - Party leader transfer logic
   - Any other methods that modify party state
7. Ensure backward compatibility with existing party features.
8. Consider edge cases such as:
   - Network disconnections during state changes
   - Server restarts during operations
   - Multiple simultaneous requests from the same user

The implementation should prioritize data consistency while minimizing performance impact.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing for this task should be comprehensive and include:

1. Unit tests:
   - Create mock scenarios that simulate race conditions
   - Test all edge cases identified in the implementation
   - Verify proper error handling and recovery

2. Integration tests:
   - Test the party system with the new concurrency controls in place
   - Verify that party state remains consistent across all operations
   - Ensure all party features continue to work as expected

3. Load/stress testing:
   - Simulate high-concurrency scenarios with many simultaneous join/leave requests
   - Measure performance impact under load
   - Verify system stability under extreme conditions

4. Automated test suite:
   - Create automated tests that can be run as part of CI/CD pipeline
   - Include tests that specifically target race conditions

5. Manual testing scenarios:
   - Have multiple testers attempt to join/leave parties simultaneously
   - Test across different network conditions
   - Verify behavior during server restarts or network interruptions

6. Documentation verification:
   - Review documentation for clarity and completeness
   - Ensure all edge cases and error scenarios are documented
   - Verify that the implementation matches the documented approach

Success criteria: No data inconsistencies occur when multiple users perform party operations simultaneously, all operations complete successfully or fail gracefully with appropriate error messages, and system performance remains within acceptable parameters.

tasks.title: Task #501: Audit and Refactor Integration Points Between Party System and Related Systems
tasks.description: Document all integration points between the Party System and the Reputation, Emotion, and Interaction systems, then refactor the code to implement robust interfaces or event-driven architecture for improved synchronization.
tasks.details:
This task requires a comprehensive audit of all existing integration points between the Party System and three related systems: Reputation, Emotion, and Interaction. Begin by mapping all current data flows, API calls, and shared state between these systems. Document each integration point including the direction of data flow, frequency of updates, data dependencies, and potential race conditions or synchronization issues.

After documentation is complete, refactor the integration code following these principles:
1. Replace direct API calls with well-defined interfaces that decouple the systems
2. Implement an event-driven architecture using a publish-subscribe pattern where appropriate
3. Create clear contracts between systems with proper error handling
4. Ensure all state changes are properly synchronized to prevent data inconsistencies
5. Add logging at integration boundaries for improved debugging and monitoring
6. Consider implementing a message queue for asynchronous updates between systems
7. Ensure backward compatibility or provide migration paths for existing functionality
8. Update the Party System to properly handle the newly refactored integration points with the Morale and Loyalty Tracking System (from Task #500)
9. Ensure integration with the Party Reputation system (from Task #499) follows the new architecture
10. Verify that edge case handling for party dynamics (from Task #498) remains functional with the new integration approach

The refactoring should prioritize maintainability, testability, and reducing tight coupling between systems while maintaining all existing functionality.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing for this refactoring task should be comprehensive and multi-layered:

1. Unit Tests:
   - Create unit tests for each new interface and event handler
   - Mock dependencies to test integration points in isolation
   - Verify proper error handling and edge cases

2. Integration Tests:
   - Develop tests that verify correct data flow between systems
   - Test synchronization under various load conditions
   - Verify event propagation works correctly across system boundaries
   - Test scenarios where multiple systems update shared state concurrently

3. Regression Tests:
   - Create a test suite that verifies all existing functionality still works
   - Ensure the Morale and Loyalty system (Task #500) still receives proper updates
   - Verify Party Reputation checks (Task #499) function correctly
   - Confirm edge case handling (Task #498) remains operational

4. Performance Tests:
   - Measure and compare system performance before and after refactoring
   - Test under high load to ensure the new architecture scales appropriately
   - Verify there are no new bottlenecks introduced

5. Documentation Verification:
   - Review documentation for completeness against the actual implementation
   - Ensure all integration points are properly documented
   - Verify that documentation includes sequence diagrams and data flow descriptions

6. Code Review:
   - Conduct thorough code reviews focusing on the integration points
   - Verify adherence to the defined architecture patterns
   - Check for proper error handling and logging

The task is complete when all tests pass, documentation is verified, and code reviews are approved. A final end-to-end test should demonstrate the systems working together through various party dynamics scenarios.

tasks.title: Task #502: Implement Robust Party Data Persistence with Versioning and Recovery Mechanisms
tasks.description: Enhance the party data persistence layer to support reliable storage, versioning, data migration, and implement comprehensive recovery procedures for data loss or corruption scenarios.
tasks.details:
The implementation should focus on the following key areas:

1. **Storage Enhancement**:
   - Implement a transaction-based persistence mechanism for party data
   - Add data integrity checks (checksums, validation) before committing to storage
   - Consider implementing a write-ahead logging system for critical party data changes
   - Support atomic operations to prevent partial updates

2. **Versioning System**:
   - Design and implement a schema versioning system for party data models
   - Create version migration paths for backward compatibility
   - Store version metadata with each party record
   - Implement automatic version detection and migration during data retrieval

3. **Data Migration Framework**:
   - Build tools to safely migrate party data between schema versions
   - Support batch migration for performance optimization
   - Include validation steps to ensure data integrity during migration
   - Provide rollback capabilities for failed migrations

4. **Recovery Mechanisms**:
   - Implement point-in-time recovery using transaction logs
   - Create automated backup scheduling for party data
   - Design a recovery workflow with clear steps for different corruption scenarios
   - Build tools to validate recovered data integrity

5. **Documentation**:
   - Create comprehensive technical documentation for the persistence layer
   - Document all recovery procedures with step-by-step instructions
   - Include troubleshooting guides for common failure scenarios
   - Document integration points with related systems (Reputation, Emotion, Interaction)

This task should coordinate with the recent integration refactoring (Task #501) to ensure the persistence layer properly supports the interfaces between Party System and related systems.
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing should be comprehensive and cover all aspects of the enhanced persistence layer:

1. **Unit Tests**:
   - Test individual components of the persistence layer (storage, versioning, migration, recovery)
   - Verify data integrity checks function correctly
   - Test version detection and migration logic
   - Validate transaction logging and replay functionality

2. **Integration Tests**:
   - Test interaction between persistence layer and other system components
   - Verify integration with Reputation, Emotion, and Interaction systems
   - Test data flow through the entire system with persistence operations

3. **Performance Tests**:
   - Benchmark read/write operations with various data volumes
   - Test migration performance with large datasets
   - Measure recovery time for different corruption scenarios
   - Verify system performance under load with persistence operations

4. **Disaster Recovery Tests**:
   - Simulate various data corruption scenarios
   - Test complete recovery from backup
   - Verify point-in-time recovery functionality
   - Test partial data recovery scenarios

5. **Documentation Validation**:
   - Conduct a recovery drill following only the documented procedures
   - Have team members unfamiliar with the implementation attempt recovery using documentation
   - Verify all edge cases are covered in documentation
   - Ensure recovery time estimates are accurate

6. **Acceptance Criteria**:
   - All unit and integration tests pass with >95% code coverage
   - Recovery from simulated data corruption completes successfully within defined time parameters
   - Data integrity is maintained through migration between at least 3 different schema versions
   - Documentation successfully guides recovery without developer intervention

tasks.title: Task #504: Implement Core Trading System Improvements for Market Stability and Testing
tasks.description: Design and implement six critical trading system mechanics including transaction rollback, error handling, validation pipeline, audit trails, bundled trades, and cancellation penalties to enable stable market testing.
tasks.details:
This task requires implementing several interconnected components to enhance the trading system:

1. Transaction Rollback Mechanism:
   - Implement an atomic transaction pattern for all trade operations
   - Create a state snapshot before trade execution
   - Develop rollback procedures that restore inventory, currency, and ownership states
   - Ensure database consistency during rollbacks with proper transaction isolation

2. Error Handling Framework:
   - Design a comprehensive error classification system for trade operations
   - Implement contextual error messages with error codes and recovery suggestions
   - Create graceful degradation paths for partial system failures
   - Add detailed logging for all error conditions with relevant context

3. Trade Validation Pipeline:
   - Develop a multi-stage validation pipeline with pre-trade, execution, and post-trade phases
   - Implement plugin architecture for validation hooks at each stage
   - Create standard validators for common scenarios (inventory checks, currency verification, etc.)
   - Design an extensible validation result object with detailed failure information

4. Audit Trail System:
   - Implement immutable logging of all trade events with timestamps and participant identifiers
   - Store complete before/after states for all affected entities
   - Add transaction IDs that link related operations
   - Ensure audit data is queryable for analysis and dispute resolution

5. Bundled Trade Support:
   - Design data structures to represent multi-item trade packages
   - Implement all-or-nothing execution semantics for bundled items
   - Create UI considerations for displaying bundled trades
   - Ensure validation, rollback, and audit systems handle bundled trades correctly

6. Cancellation Penalty Framework:
   - Implement configurable penalty calculations based on time elapsed, trade value, etc.
   - Create penalty application mechanisms that affect currency, reputation, or other systems
   - Design notification system for penalty application
   - Ensure penalties are properly recorded in the audit trail

Integration Considerations:
- Coordinate with the Reputation System (see Task #501) for trade reputation impacts
- Ensure compatibility with existing inventory and currency systems
- Design for performance under high-volume trading scenarios
- Consider future extensibility for advanced market features
tasks.testStrategy:
Testing for this trading system implementation should be comprehensive and multi-layered:

1. Unit Testing:
   - Create unit tests for each component (rollback, validation, etc.) in isolation
   - Test each error condition and recovery path
   - Verify mathematical correctness of penalty calculations
   - Ensure validation rules produce expected results for edge cases

2. Integration Testing:
   - Test interactions between trading system components
   - Verify proper integration with inventory, currency, and reputation systems
   - Test database transaction integrity during concurrent operations
   - Ensure audit trail captures all required information accurately

3. Scenario Testing:
   - Create comprehensive test scenarios covering common trading patterns
   - Test high-volume trading scenarios for performance issues
   - Simulate network failures and system interruptions during trades
   - Test bundled trades with various item combinations

4. Automated Regression Testing:
   - Develop automated test suite that can be run after any system changes
   - Include performance benchmarks to detect degradation
   - Create data consistency validators to ensure system integrity

5. User Acceptance Testing:
   - Conduct supervised play-testing sessions with focus on trading
   - Collect feedback on error messages and recovery suggestions
   - Measure time to complete common trading operations
   - Evaluate user understanding of cancellation penalties

6. Chaos Testing:
   - Randomly inject failures into the trading system during operation
   - Verify rollback mechanisms restore proper state
   - Test system recovery after catastrophic failures

7. Documentation Verification:
   - Ensure all trading mechanics are properly documented
   - Verify error codes and messages match documentation
   - Confirm audit trail format matches specified requirements

Success Criteria:
- All unit and integration tests pass with >95% code coverage
- System maintains data consistency during simulated failures
- Trading operations perform within specified latency requirements
- Audit trail successfully captures all required information
- Play-testers can complete trades with minimal friction

tasks.title: Task #505: Implement Essential Market Data Persistence with Database Integration
tasks.description: Convert the current in-memory market data storage system to a persistent database implementation with proper schema design, validation, transaction support, backup capabilities, and monitoring to ensure system stability during play-testing.
tasks.details:
The implementation should focus on the following key areas:

1. Database Schema Design:
   - Create normalized schema for market data entities with appropriate relationships
   - Design tables for market data, trade offers, transaction history, and price history
   - Implement appropriate indexes for performance optimization
   - Document schema with ERD diagrams and data dictionary
   - Consider temporal aspects for historical data (price history, transaction logs)

2. Data Access Layer:
   - Implement repository pattern for data access abstraction
   - Create data models/DTOs for each entity type
   - Develop migration strategy from in-memory to database storage
   - Implement connection pooling for performance
   - Add caching layer for frequently accessed market data

3. Data Validation:
   - Implement server-side validation for all market data entities
   - Add constraint checks at database level (foreign keys, unique constraints)
   - Create validation pipeline for trade offers and transactions
   - Implement data sanitization for user inputs
   - Add logging for validation failures

4. Transaction Support:
   - Implement unit of work pattern for transaction management
   - Ensure ACID compliance for all market operations
   - Add transaction isolation level configuration
   - Implement rollback mechanisms for failed operations
   - Create transaction logs for audit purposes

5. Backup and Recovery:
   - Implement scheduled database backups
   - Create point-in-time recovery capability
   - Develop data integrity verification tools
   - Document recovery procedures
   - Test recovery scenarios

6. Monitoring:
   - Add performance metrics collection for database operations
   - Implement query performance monitoring
   - Create alerts for database issues (space, connections, etc.)
   - Add logging for critical database operations
   - Develop dashboard for database health visualization

Integration Considerations:
- Ensure backward compatibility with existing market system interfaces
- Implement feature flags to gradually roll out database persistence
- Consider read/write splitting for performance if needed
- Plan for potential data migration of existing market data
- Coordinate with Task #504 (Core Trading System) to ensure compatibility
tasks.testStrategy:

   - Validate data access patterns and query correctness

   - Verify transaction handling and rollback scenarios
   - Test data model conversions and mappings

2. Integration Testing:
   - Test database schema creation and migrations
   - Verify foreign key constraints and relationships
   - Test transaction isolation in concurrent scenarios
   - Validate backup and restore functionality
   - Test connection pooling under load

3. Performance Testing:
   - Benchmark read/write operations against performance requirements
   - Test system under various load conditions
   - Measure query execution times for critical operations
   - Verify index effectiveness
   - Test caching mechanisms

4. Failure Recovery Testing:
   - Simulate database connection failures
   - Test system behavior during transaction failures
   - Verify data integrity after recovery procedures
   - Test backup restoration process
   - Validate monitoring alerts during failure scenarios

5. Migration Testing:
   - Test data migration from in-memory to database storage
   - Verify data integrity after migration
   - Test rollback procedures for failed migrations
   - Measure downtime during migration process

6. Acceptance Criteria:
   - All market operations persist correctly to the database

   - Backup and recovery completes within defined SLA

   - System can handle play-test load without data loss or corruption

tasks.title: Task #506: Enhance Core Pricing Algorithm for Economic Balance in Play-Testing
tasks.description: Implement six essential pricing features including supply/demand curves, price boundaries, rarity modifiers, housing rules, market manipulation detection, and regional variations to establish basic economic balance during play-testing.
tasks.details:

1. Basic Supply/Demand Curve Implementation:
   - Create a configurable curve function that adjusts prices based on item availability and player demand
   - Implement time-decay factors to account for historical transaction data
   - Design adaptive parameters that can be tuned during testing
   - Ensure the algorithm handles edge cases like new items or rarely traded goods

   - Create specific economic scenarios for play-testers to evaluate
   - Develop feedback collection tools for economic balance issues
   - Implement monitoring dashboards to track key economic indicators
   - Establish a process for rapid algorithm adjustment based on play-test feedback

6. Documentation and Validation:
   - Create comprehensive documentation of all pricing rules and formulas

tasks.title: Task #507: Implement Basic Market Accessibility Features for Play-Testing

tasks.details:
